question: Question_03_(a)
statement:
Let

\begin{align*}S = \left\{[x_1, x_2, x_3]^T:\, x_1 + x_2 + x_3 = 0\right\}\end{align*}

be the subspace of vectors in $\mathbb R^3$ whose components sum to
zero.

\textbf{(a)} Find a matrix \emph{A} so that \emph{S} is the null space
of \emph{A}, i.e., \emph{S = N(A)}.
sols:
The definition of \emph{S} contains a dot product which reveals the
vector orthogonal to \emph{S}:

\begin{align*}
S &= \left\{[x_1, x_2, x_3]^T:\, x_1 + x_2 + x_3 = 0\right\} \\
&= \left\{[x_1, x_2, x_3]^T:\, \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = 0\right\}\end{align*}

Since the vector $\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$ is
orthogonal to \emph{S}, and the nullspace of \emph{A} ( which is
\emph{S}) is orthogonal to the row space of \emph{A}, we can choose any
matrix \emph{A} whose row space is spanned by
$\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$. Such as
$A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$ or
$A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ \pi & \pi & \pi \end{bmatrix}.$
hints: How are the row space and the nullspace of of a matrix related?

The nullspace of a matrix \emph{A} is the orthogonal complement of the
row space. Can you find a vector orthogonal to \emph{S}?
